keyTakeAways: A daylight robbery at the Louvre in Paris involved four masked thieves who used power tools to break into the museum in under eight minutes.
The stolen jewellery, valued at €88 million, included a diamond and emerald necklace from Napoleon I, a tiara worn by Empress Eugenie, and items once owned by Queen Marie-Amelie.
Investigators found a damaged crown belonging to Empress Eugenie on the escape route, suggesting the thieves dropped it in haste.
Security failures were identified, including the absence of CCTV in one in three rooms and a failure of the alarm system to activate.
The thieves used a modified truck with a mechanical lift to access the Gallery of Apollo via a balcony near the Seine River.
Two thieves cut through a glass window using a battery-powered disc cutter and threatened guards, prompting evacuation.
The thieves attempted to set fire to their vehicle but were stopped by a museum staff member.
They fled on scooters, and experts believe the items were likely broken down into metals and gems and smuggled out of the country.
French President Emmanuel Macron described the heist as an attack on France’s heritage.
Justice Minister Gérald Darmanin criticized security protocols, calling the incident a 'terrible image' for France.
French prosecutors believe the perpetrators are professionals due to the organized and rapid nature of the crime.
Museum curator Laure Beccuau stated the greater loss is to France’s historical heritage, not just financial.
She emphasized that destroying the jewellery would result in a loss of value, suggesting the thieves might not profit fully from the theft.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In a daring daylight robbery at the Louvre in Paris, four masked thieves used a modified truck and power tools to breach the museum within eight minutes, stealing high-value jewellery including a necklace from Napoleon I and a tiara from Empress Eugenie. The stolen items are estimated at €88 million, though experts fear they have already been broken down and smuggled out. Security failures, including missing CCTV and a failed alarm system, were identified. The incident has prompted national outrage and calls for improved protection of cultural heritage, with President Emmanuel Macron and Justice Minister Gérald Darmanin condemning the breach as an attack on France’s identity and history. Authorities suspect a professional team, and experts warn that the items may be gone within two days, with the only hope being that the thieves do not melt the jewellery, which would cause irreversible loss to historical culture.
title: Louvre heist: Stolen jewellery worth €88m, prosecutor says
